It seems that you learned your course wasn't an actual linear algebra course, but I would like to point out that many colleges and universities are creating intro-level linear algebra courses with no prerequisites. There is no inherent need to learn calculus before learning linear algebra. There are some applications of linear algebra that also require calculus, but you can learn almost all of the theory of linear algebra and tons of applications without knowing any calculus at all.   Mainly, I'm replying for ProfessorDave's sake, since he said linear algebra is done after calculus. Although traditionally, it has been that way, there's no inherent reason why it has to be done that way, and there are plenty of colleges which are changing their curriculums so you can do linear algebra without having taken calculus.
